p: Distinct changes in the climate response of juniper trees were observed across the study area and with respect to elevation ( Fig 5). Focusing on the temperature response in JJA, sites located in Zaamin (UZ), Kyrgyz Ata and Karakuldja (southern KG) and Karakol (eastern KG), showed increased negative responses to high temperatures ( Fig 5A). In contrast, junipers in Chimgan (UZ) seem to be less stressed by warm temperatures in recent decades, and significant changes in correlations were observed at B2H with r = 0.47 ( p<0.01; from r = -0.22 to r = 0.25) and B2L with r = 0.41 ( p<0.05; from r = -0.35 to r = 0.06) ( S3A Table). Thus, during 1935â€“1964, there was an increasingly positive influence of temperatures with increasing altitude ( Fig 5B). On the contrary, in the past 30 years at several high elevation sites, junipers have become negatively influenced by high temperatures ( Fig 5B), where the most pronounced shifts are seen in the high-pass filtered data ( Fig 5B, dashed trend lines).
